qas.question: Inside of what can the molecular circadian clock operate?
By functioning within a single, what is the system?
What section of the brain periodically releases hormones?
How are sleep and wake cycles as well as body functions coordinated?
What do body hormone receptors do with the body's organs?
What requires multiple cells to function?

plausible_answers.text: different cells may communicate with each other

qas.question: What results in a synchronized output electrical signals?
what section of the brain rarely releases hormones?
Where in the body are receptors for electrical signals located?

plausible_answers.text: sleep/wake, body temperature, thirst, and appetite

qas.question: What is timed independently of the biological clock?

context: It is now known that the molecular <b5_0>circadian clock<b5_0/> can function within a <a0_0>single cell<a0_0/>; i.e., it is <a1_0>cell-autonomous<a1_0/>. This was shown by Gene Block in isolated mollusk BRNs.[clarification needed] At the same time, <b6_0>different cells may communicate with each other<b6_0/> resulting in a synchronised output of electrical signaling. These may interface with <a2_0><b7_0>endocrine<b7_0/> glands<a2_0/> of the brain to result in periodic release of hormones. The receptors for these hormones may be located <b8_0>far across the body<b8_0/> and <a4_0>synchronise<a4_0/> the peripheral clocks of various organs. Thus, the information of the time of the day as relayed by the eyes travels to the clock in the brain, and, through that, clocks in the rest of the body may be synchronised. This is how the timing of, for example, <b9_0>sleep/wake, body temperature, thirst, and appetite<b9_0/> are coordinately controlled by the <a3_0>biological clock<a3_0/>.[citation needed]
